p: The dominant use of leaves presents little threat to the survival of medicinal plants. This encourages frequent and safe utilization of the plants for herbal preparations. Roots and root structures such as tubers and rhizomes are rich sources of potent bioactive chemical compounds [ 33], but their frequent use in antimalarial preparations may threaten the survival of the plant species used. For example, Zanthoxylum chalybeum and African wild olive ( Olea europaea) have been reported to be threatened due to improper harvesting methods [ 2]. Thus, proper harvesting strategies and conservation measures are inevitable if sustainable utilization of such medicinal plants are to be realized.
